1 Journal of Molecular Catalysis, 73 (1992) 249-263 M2856 249 Characterization of Cr/silica ethylene polymerization catalyst by TPO/TPR and FT-IR Chang Soo Kim and Seong Ihl Woo* Department of Chemical Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, P.O. Box 150, Cheong Ryang, Seoul (South Korea) (Received November 5, 1991; revised January 13, 1992) Abstract A Cr/silica catalyst with a Cr loading of 1 wt.% has been prepared by impregnating an aqueous solution of chromium(III) acetate onto Davison 952 silica. The characterization of the surface chromium species formed during the activation process was performed using TPO/R (temperature-programmed oxidation/reduction) and FT-IR spectroscopy. During activation with dry air, chromium(III) acetate was stabilized on the surface as a hexavalent chromium species. The average oxidation numbers of surface chromium species after activation at 823, 923, 1023, 1123, and 1223 K are found to be 6.0, 5.4, 5.1, 4.2, and 3.7, respectively. The amounts of the Cr(VI) species varied with activation temperature. The fraction of Cr(VI) atoms existing in monochromate form increased with increasing activation temperature, which was a result of the decrease in the fraction of dichromate and/or polychromate. The OH stretching bands of Cr/silica prepared by the reduction of Cr(VI)/silica with CO and the stretching bands of CO adsorbed on it indicate the existence of three distinct types of Cr(II) (CrA(II), CrB(I1), and Crc(II)), whose amounts are strongly dependent on the activation temperature. Introduction Owing to its commercial importance, the Phillips Cr/silica ethylene polymerization catalyst has been the subject of extensive investigation. Many of the studies were concerned with the nature and identification of the catalytically active species and the polymerization mechanisms [ 1 ]. To obtain an activated catalyst, supported chromium precursor species have to be calcined in dry air at a high temperature (> 750 K). This produces chromium in the hexavalent state stabilized on the silica surface. This is due to the formation of a surface chromate or perhaps dichromate ester in which each chromium atom is directly linked to the support. Whether the Cr(VI) atoms exist as a monochromate or as a dichromate is still controversial, despite numerous previous studies. Hogan [2] and McDaniel [3] measured the change in hydroxyl population with different coverage of Cr(VI) and concluded that Cr03 exists mainly as a chromate. On the other hand, Krauss [ 4 ], Zecchina et al. [ 5 ], Groeneveld et al. [ 6 ], Fzbini et al. [ 7 ], and Rebenstorf *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$5.00 0 1992 - Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved 250 and Larsson [8 ] studied the catalyst using IR and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy and concluded that chromium atoms are stabilized mainly as a dichromate. Also, Hill and co-workers [9] studied the photoluminescence of the catalyst and reported that chromium atoms are stabilized onto the support as chromate, dichromate, and polychromate. Krauss and Stach [ 10 ] reported that the activated catalyst, hexavalent chromium, can be quantitatively reduced by CO at 623 K to divalent chromium. An Italian group detected four distinct types of Cr(II), which differ in the number of coordinated oxides [5, 7, 11-15]. They reported the IR spectra of CO, NO, etc. adsorbed on the reduced catalyst. Krauss et al. also detected several types of Cr(II) species that differ in their reactivities [16]. In order to gain further information about the formation of the surface chromium species and its characteristics, we have studied the activated and CO-reduced forms of Cr(III) acetate/silica using temperature programmed reduction/oxidation and FT-IR spectroscopy. Experimental Catalyst preparation The catalyst was prepared with silica (Davison grade 952MS) having a pore volume of 1.6 cm' g-' and a surface area of about 280 m2 g-1. It was impregnated with an aqueous solution of chromium(III) acetate. The silica was suspended in a relatively large amount of solution, and the suspension was dried in a rotary evaporator for about 10 h. During this procedure the temperature did not exceed 323 K. The catalyst was further dried in an oven at 380 K for 12 h. The prepared catalyst was light green in color and contained 1.0 wt.% chromium. Several other types of chromium(III) acetate/ silica catalysts were also prepared using silicas with different properties, which are listed under Discussion. Temperature- rogrammed oxidation/reduction (TPO/R) Temperature-programmed oxidation/reduction (TPO/R) measurements were performed with a gas-flow system consisting of a gas purifier, flow controllers, a reactor, and a heating system. A quartz tube equipped with a sintered glass disk was used as a reactor. A PID-type temperature controller was used to obtain a linear heating rate. A quadrupole mass spectrometer (VG, SX 300) was used to measure the concentrations of gas species of interest. A part of the effluent gas at the outlet of the reactor was introduced into the mass spectrometer through a capillary tube, which was heated to prevent condensation. Quantitative analyses of TPR were also carried out using a gas chromatography (thermal conductivity detector) instrument. TPR and TPO experiments were carried out in a fluidized bed with 5 vol.96 HZ/N2 and dry air, respectively. The linear velocity of gases in a fluidized bed was kept at 0.7 cm sec-'. 0.5 g of sample was heated at a rate of 10 K min-' from room temperature to 1223 K. For TPR experiments, 251 samples were fluidized in dry air at 823-1223 K for 2 h to activate the catalyst. After activation at the desired temperature, samples were flushed with dry nitrogen at 623 K for 0.5 h and cooled down to room temperature under nitrogen to avoid adsorption of oxygen during cooling. All the gases were predried through activated alumina and a 5A type molecular sieve column. All the gases except air were also deoxygenated through a Ridox (Fischer Sci.) column. FT-IR spectroscopy Wafers for FT-IR were prepared by pressing the catalyst powder (15-25 mg cm-Z) at 270 kg cm-2. Wafers were pretreated in a quartz cell equipped with KBr windows. In situ thermal treatment of wafers can be performed with this cell. The wafer was heated to the activation temperature (10 K min-') in dry air and calcined at this temperature for 2 h. After activation the wafer was cooled down to 623 K and evacuated to 1 x 10-6 torr (1 torr=133.3 N m-2) at this temperature. To obtain the IR spectrum of the activated catalyst, the wafer was further cooled down to room temperature in vacuum. The IR spectrum of the activated catalyst was recorded at room temperature. The activated catalyst wafer was reduced at 623 K with CO for 0.5 h. CO was evacuated at 623 K, and a spectrum of the reduced catalyst wafer was recorded at room temperature. The IR spectra of CO adsorbed on the catalyst wafer were also recorded at room temperature. Infrared spectra were recorded with an FT-IR spectrometer BOMEM MB-102 with a resolution of 4 cm-1; 500 scans were accumulated. Results Temperature programmed otion (TPO) TPO of fresh chromium(III) acetate/silica catalyst was carried out in dry air and at a heating rate of 10 K min-'. 02 was consumed, and water and carbon dioxide were produced, during the TPO experiment. The partial pressures of these compounds analyzed with a quadrupole mass spectrometer are shown in Fig. 1. There are three positive peaks due to HZO, one positive COZ peak, and two negative peaks due to O2. FT-IR The IR spectra of the catalyst activated at various temperatures are shown in Fig. 2. The band at ca. 907 cm-' is assigned to the Cr=O stretching band of Cr(VI) [5, 17]. The intensity of this band indirectly gives the relative amount of Cr=O bonds formed on the surface of the activated catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3, the ratio of integrated intensity normalized with the integrated intensity of the band of the catalyst activated at 1023 K varies with the activation temperature. The intensity of the Cr=O band has a maximum at 823 K, and decreases as the activation temperature is raised above this value. Discussion Formation of chromium species during activation In the case of the Cr03/silica catalyst, the formation of a definite surface phase during the activation process has already been reported, together with some degradation of Cr(VI) at the surface to a lower valence state [2, 4-7]. The anchorage of Cr03 onto the surface is assumed to involve esterification of suitable silanols, yielding surface chromates or dichromates. Hogan [2] reported that this process takes place below 393 K, while Groeneveld et al. 257 [6] and, Fixbini et al. [7] claimed that this process occurs at much higher temperatures. In the case of the chromium(III) acetate/silica catalyst, TPO spectroscopy gives information on the formation of surface chromium species. As shown in Fig. 1, three positive peaks due to H20, one positive C02 peak, and two negative peaks due to 02 appear during TPO. The H20 peak around 460 K is attributed to H20 adsorbed on the catalyst. The relatively broad H20 peak appearing above 720 K is due to the dehydroxylation of surface hydroxyl groups. The small peak around 650 K indicates the formation of water by the oxidation of the acetate group. This interpretation is confirmed by the production of carbon dioxide and the consumption of oxygen around 630 K. The difference in the peak temperature of C02 (630 K) and H20 (650 K) can be explained by the interaction of the H20 produced with the catalyst. The consumption of 02 without production of C02 also appears around 460 K. Although the mechanism of 02 consumption at this temperature is not fully understood, it may be due to the partial oxidation of chromium(III) acetate. Cornet and Burwell have reported that a species of Cr(VI) is obtained by heating the chromium(III) acetate with air at 413 K [ 19 ]. Therefore, it can be said that one species of Cr(VI) was formed around 460 K and the other Cr(VI) species was formed at 550-720 K. The color of fresh chromium(III) acetate/silica changed from light green to yellow or orange after oxidation with air above 550 K. As shown in Fig. 3, the amount of Cr(VI) reaches a maximum at 823 K and decreases above 823 K. The melting point of bulk Cr03 is 473 K. Bulk Cr03 is more thermally unstable than supported Cr03 and begins to decompose into Cr203 and 02 in air at 530 K [2, 20]. When the chromium loading is made higher and the surface area of the support is made smaller, the amount of Cr(VI) stabilized on the support becomes smaller [2, 21 ]. In our study chromium loading was fixed at 1 wt.%. The decrease in the amount of Cr(VI) stabilized on the support above 823 K is mainly attributed to the thermal decomposition of Cr(VI) oxide and partly to the decrease in the surface area of the support. Also, the average oxidation state of chromium stabilized onto the support at various activation temperatures can be calculated from the amount of H2 consumed during TPR. First, we must know the valence state of chromium after H2 reduction. Several researchers have reported the valence state of H2-reduced chromium. Groeneveld et al. reported that it has a value of 2-3 [6]. Hill and Ohlmann [22], Parlitz et al. [23], and Ehrhardt et al. [24] reported that after H2 reduction the valence state of chromium is 3. Since they used a small flow rate of H2, 3-14 ml min-1, reduced chromium could be easily oxidized with the H20 produced during TPR. Since the H20 produced during TPR can interact with the catalyst, the valence- state of H2-reduced chromium is dependent on kinetic factors such as gas velocity and heating rate [6, 25]. On the other hand, Finch assumed that the chromium species supported on silica after H2 reduction has a valence state of 2 [26]. In our study we assumed the valence state of H2-reduced catalyst to be Cr(II) 258 because we effectively removed the H20 produced during TPR by fluidizing the catalyst with a flow rate through the bed of 0.7 cm sec-1. Consequently, the average oxidation numbers of activated chromium were calculated to be 6.0, 5.4, 5.1, 4.2, and 3.7 at the activation temperatures of 823, 923, 1023, 1123, and 1223 K, respectively. The average oxidation states of chromium species at various activation temperatures are shown in Table 1. The average oxidation number of chromium species activated between 823 and 1023 K is 5-6. This agrees well with the results of McDaniel [3] and Finch [26]. The average oxidation numbers at 1123 K and 1223 K are 4.2 and 3.7, respectively. The low oxidation states can perhaps be attributed to the thermal decomposition of Cr(VI) to inactive Cr(III), which is not reduced with Hz [6]. Cimino et al. studied 1 wt.% chromium catalyst supported on Carbosil silica (surface area 210 m2 g-1) using ESCA and reported that formation of Cr203, inactive Cr(III), begins at 873 K [27]. Although the color of the activated catalyst turns to light green at higher activation temperatures (above 1023 K), no XRD pattern for Cr203 was observed, perhaps because the size of the oxide particle is too small to be detected. This is reasonable, because 1 wt.% chromium is dispersed on Davison 952 silica, which has a pore volume of 1.6 ml g-1 and a surface area of about 280 m2 g-1. If we assume that Cr(VI) and inactive Cr(III) are the main components of the activated chromium species, the percent decomposition of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) can be evaluated from the average oxidation state (shown in Table 1). In the case of activated catalyst at 1223 K, 79g'o of Cr(VI) was decomposed to inactive Cr(III). Characteristics of surface chromium species Activated catalysts Several types of chromate can be stabilized onto the surface during the activation process, although their relative populations are not clearly understood [2-9]. The TPR spectrum obtained after exposing the activated catalyst to moisture gives a new peak around 640 K, which is accompanied by the shift of the original peak temperature around 745 K to higher temperature. Hogan [2] and Groeneveld et al. [6] reported that H20 hydrolyzes the Si-O-Cr bonding to produce a chromium oxide species, which is mobile on the surface of silica. This mobile chromium species can be agglomerized to form large chromium oxide species, which can be reduced with HZ at the lower temperature of 640 K. To study the variation of the peak temperature of TPR, additional chromium(III) acetate/silica catalysts with chromium loadings of 0.1, 0.5, 1, and 5 wt.% were prepared, using silicas of different properties. The physical properties of various silicas are shown in Table 2. The TPR results after all the samples were activated with dry air at 1023 K are shown in Fig. 9. The temperature at which the TPR peak appeared decreased as the average pore radius of silica increased and the surface area decreased. The probability of agglomerization increased as the surface area decreased. Accordingly, easily reducible chromium oxide can be formed. In other words, dichromate and/or polychromate rather than monochromate are easily formed on these silicas. The TPR peak temperature shifted to higher temperatures as the chromium loading decreased and the surface area increased. More monochromate can be formed at lower loadings of chromium and on the silica of higher surface area because the amount of interaction between chromium oxide and support is high in these cases. Therefore the appearance of the new TPR peak at around 640 K after contact with moisture can be attributed to the reduction of hydrolyzed 260 dichromate and/or polychromate. The shift of the peak temperature to a higher temperature does not indicate that more stabilized chromium oxide was newly formed, but rather indicates that a chromium oxide species that is difficult to hydrolyze remains on the surface and is reduced at higher temperature. The TPR peak temperature of the catalyst increased as the activation temperature increased, as shown in Fig. 7. The TPR peak temperatures of the catalyst activated at 723 and 823 K are the same, which indicates that dichromate and/or polychromate do not decompose to Cr(HI) species below 823 K. At the activation temperature of 923 K, slight decomposition was observed, as was a small shift of the TPR peak to higher temperature, as indicated by the decrease in the area of the peak and the peak temperature in Fig. 7. The TPR peak temperature increased to 798 K at the activation temperature of 1223 K. As the activation temperature increased, dichromate and/or polychromate that were stabilized onto the surface less strongly than chromate can thermally decompose to the inactive Cr(III) during the activation process. As shown in Fig. 7, the area of the TPR peaks decreased as the percentage of dichromate and/or polychromate decomposed to Cr(III) increased, because Cr(III) cannot be reduced with HZ in the range of our TPR temperatures. The IR spectra of adsorbed CO on the catalyst reduced with CO, shown in Fig. 5, give further evidence for this explanation. The 2097 cm-1 band, which was assigned to the bridging CO on the paired chromium site [11], decreased in intensity as the activation temperature increased, up to 1023 K. This band disappeared above 1023 K. The increase in the fraction of monochromate resulting from the decrease in the fraction of dichromate and/or polychromate as the activation temperature increased causes the TPR peak temperature to be shifted to higher temperature. CO-reduced catalyst It is well known that the hexavalent chromium of the activated catalyst is easily reduced to divalent chromium with CO at 623 K without rearrangement during the reduction [ 1 ]. Several types of Cr(II) species have been reported [5, 7, 11-16]. However, the interaction between Cr(II) and the OH group was not investigated previously. Both activated catalysts and CO-reduced catalysts always have an OH stretching band at 3745 cm-1. The interesting point is that CO reduction of activated catalyst causes a decrease in the intensity of the band at 3745 cm-1, which is accompanied by the appearance of two positive bands at about 3725 and 3600 cm-', as shown in Fig. 4. The sum of the integrated intensities of the two positive bands is larger than the intensity of the negative band at 3745 cm-1. This cannot be explained by the increase in the number of hydroxyl groups during CO reduction, because the catalysts were activated at temperatures above 823 K and then CO reduction was performed with dry CO at 623 K. The hydroxyls present in the activated catalysts cannot be removed by the CO at 623 K. The hydroxyl population on the catalyst was found to decrease when exposed to CO above 870 K [28]. It is also 261 known that the integrated intensity of the perturbed hydroxyl group is found to be greatly increased by the hydrogen-bonding interaction [29]. The appearance of two positive bands at lower frequencies occurred simultaneously with the decrease in the intensity of the band at 3745 cm-1, which is not hydrogen-bonded. These two positive bands originate from the hydroxyl groups that are hydrogen-bonded, or that are in a more polar environment, causing a downward shift of the frequency. This indicates that some of the isolated hydroxyls interact with Cr(H) species. Considerable numbers of hydroxyls remain even in the catalyst activated above 1023 K. The hydroxyls were titrated with TiC14, and the HCl liberated was measured with a volumetric apparatus equipped with an oil manometer. The hydroxyl populations determined by this method are shown in Table 3. 1.49-1.84 hydroxyls per total chromium still remain on the catalyst activated at various temperatures. The oxygen atoms of the nearest hydroxyls tend to interact with the d electrons of Cr(II), which decreases the strength of the O-H bond. This results in a red shift of the OH band. Therefore, the two positive bands at 3725 and 3600 cm-1 can be attributed to the interaction between Cr(II) and its nearest hydroxyls. The band at 3725 cm-1 can be assigned to the OH stretching band, in which a single OH group interacts with Cr(II). However, the band at 3600 cm-1 might be due to two OH groups interacting with one Cr(II). The IR spectra of adsorbed CO on the reduced chromium give more information about the interaction of OH groups with Cr(H). The IR bands of chemisorbed CO at 2179 and 2188 cm-1 indicate that there are two kinds of chemisorption sites on the reduced catalyst. The intensities of both bands increased with increasing activation temperature up to 1023 K, then decreased considerably above 1023 K. This cannot be explained by considering only the change in the hydroxyl group concentration with activation temperature. If one of these bands is due to interactions with OH groups, the peak due to CO chemisorbed on Cr(II) must increase in intensity, because the concentration of the OH group decreases with increasing activation temperature, as shown in Table 3. A Cr/silica catalyst with a Cr loading of 1 wt.% has been prepared by impregnating an aqueous solution of chromium(III) acetate onto Davison 952 silica. The characterization of the surface chromium species formed during the activation process was performed using TPO/R (temperature-programmed oxidation/reduction) and FT—IR spectroscopy. During activation with dry air, chromium(III) acetate was stabilized on the surface as a hexavalent chromium species. The average oxidation numbers of surface chromium species after activation at 823, 923, 1023, 1123, and 1223 K are found to be 6.0, 5.4, 5.1, 4.2, and 3.7, respectively. The amounts of the Cr(VI) species varied with activation temperature. The fraction of Cr(VI) atoms existing in monochromate form increased with increasing activation temperature, which was a result of the decrease in the fraction of dichromate and/or polychromate. The OH stretching bands of Cr/silica prepared by the reduction of Cr(VI)/silica with CO and the stretching bands of CO adsorbed on it indicate the existence of three distinct types of Cr(II) (CrA(II), CrB(II), and CrC(II)), whose amounts are strongly dependent on the activation temperature.
